cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to major themes in the development of Greek and Roman civilization, literature and culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Classical Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. 2-3 video-lectures, ranging from 1-1.5 hrs, will be posted weekly. There will be a graded participation component requiring either participation in a weekly synchronous discussion (Friday 12-1 pm) or direct email contact with the instructor. All material will be available through Quercus, and students may need to use Blackboard Collaborate.

cmCourseInfo.description: The study of technical and scientific terms derived from Latin and Greek: word elements, formation, analysis. The course is designed to give students in any field of specialization a better grasp of the derivation and basic meaning of English words derived from Latin and Greek elements.
cmCourseInfo.title: Latin & Greek in Scientific Terminology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course. "Lecturettes" on pertinent course material will be posted weekly and can be accessed asynchronously. Students will also meet for synchronous online tutorials 1hr per week on Mondays between 5-8pm. Students will be automatically assigned to a 1 hr slot in this period. Students need  the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the myths and legends of ancient Greece (and their extension to Rome) with some consideration of their role in ancient and modern literature and art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Classical Mythology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. 
Lectures will be given twice a week as a 2-3hr slideshow presentation, delivered asynchronously.
Students will have opportunities to ask questions and clarifications about lecture content through online discussion boards and weekly office hours. 
Students need PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: A historical survey of the most significant features in the development of the civilization and state of ancient Rome from the mythical beginnings to the fourth century C.E.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Roman History

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as 2-3hr online videos twice a week asynchronously. Live lectures will be given twice a week in an online webinar class (Tuesdays and Thursdays, 2–5pm EST). Students can tune in and so will have the opportunity to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content. These lectures will be recorded and posted afterwards for students to access on their own time as well. Students need PowerPoint and/or Adobe Reader and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of one or more of the epic poems of Greek and Roman antiquity (e. g. The Iliad and Odyssey of Homer and the Aeneid of Virgil).
cmCourseInfo.title: Greek and Roman Epic

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given asynchronously, twice weekly (airing on Tuesday and Thursday afternoon/evening), as 2-hour videos (or less) employing PowerPoint and recorded audio.  Students will be encouraged to email the instructor at any time with questions about lecture and course content. Evaluation will be done in the forms of: 1) weekly online, multiple choice, timed quizzes, using the Quercus "Quizzes" function. Students will have a 24 hour period (on Fridays) in which to take the quizzes. 2) three 'take-home' format exams (2 midterms and a final) which will be assigned due dates and which will be 'open-book' in nature. These will be submitted using the Quercus "Assignments" function. All readings will be provided via scan (meaning some sort of pdf reader will be required) or hyperlink.

cmCourseInfo.description: The role in Roman society and culture of public spectacles, including the chariot-races, the gladiatorial games, executions, and triumphal processions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Spectacle in the Roman World

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as 2-3hr online videos per week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for a synchronous online webinar class 1 hr per week (Monday or Wednesday 6-7pm depending on schedules) in which to engage in seminar discussion. Students need Power Point and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of the representation of ancient Greece and/ or Rome in cinema.
cmCourseInfo.title: Classical Antiquity and the Cinema

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online synchronous course, meeting MW 5-8 PM (Toronto time). The first hour of each class will consist of a lecture given by the instructor, which all students must attend. For the next two hours, students will attend one of two 1-hour discussion sections (6-7 or 7-8 PM). Students must have access to the internet in order to attend class sessions over Blackboard Collaborate, and in order to stream the films assigned for class (links to these films will be provided).

cmCourseInfo.description: An instructor-supervised group project in an off-campus setting. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rep. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Excursions

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Enrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/focus/course/rop
